feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued June 02 at 6:00AM AKDT until June 02 at 9:00PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM AKDT THIS EVENING FOR HIGH TEMPERATURES, LOW HUMIDITY, AND BREEZY CONDITIONS FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONE 019... * AFFECTED AREA...Fire weather zone 019. * WIND...Up to 15 mph. * HUMIDITY...As low as 14 percent with temperatures in the mid

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued June 02 at 6:00AM AKDT until June 02 at 9:00PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM 10 AM THIS MORNING TO 9 PM AKDT THIS EVENING FOR HIGH TEMPERATURES, LOW HUMIDITY, AND BREEZY CONDITIONS FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONE 025... The National Weather Service in Juneau has issued a Red Flag Warning, which is in effect from 10 AM this morning to 9 PM AKDT this evening. The Fire Weather Watch is no longer in effect.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Juneau Borough and Northern Admiralty Island

entry.title: Dense Fog Advisory issued June 02 at 1:47AM AKDT until June 02 at 10:00AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...DENSE FOG ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM AKDT THIS MORNING... * WHAT...Visibility one quarter mile or less in dense fog. * WHERE...Cape Decision to Salisbury Sound Coastal Area, including Sitka. * WHEN...Until 10 AM AKDT this morning. * IMPACTS...Hazardous driving conditions due to low visibility.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cape Decision to Salisbury Sound Coastal Area

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 01 at 8:54AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...INCREASED FIRE DANGER FOR THE REMAINDER OF THIS WEEK... Conditions remain dry across Southeast Alaska and temperatures will continue to rise to the upper 70s and lower 80s across much of the region over the next few days. Fine fuels are dry and there is a risk of camp fires getting out of control. Winds will remain light, which is a mitigating circumstance working in our favor.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Chichagof Island; Glacier Bay; Haines Borough and Lynn Canal; Juneau Borough and Northern Admiralty Island; Taiya Inlet and Klondike Highway

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued May 31 at 1:53PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...FLOOD ADVISORY FOR SNOWMELT NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 2 PM AKDT MONDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by snowmelt continues due to warmer temperatures. * WHERE...Including the following area, Copper River Basin. * WHEN...Until 200 PM AKDT Monday.

entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued June 02 at 11:23AM CDT until June 02 at 12:15PM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: The National Weather Service in Birmingham has issued a * Severe Thunderstorm Warning for... Southeastern Marion County in northwestern Alabama... Northwestern Fayette County in west central Alabama... Northern Lamar County in west central Alabama... * Until 1215 PM CDT.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 02 at 11:21AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of southern Marion, northwestern Fayette and northern Lamar Counties through NOON CDT... At 1120 AM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near Beaverton, or 8 miles east of Sulligent, moving northeast at 20 mph. HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph and penny size hail. SOURCE...Radar indicated.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 02 at 11:19AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of southwestern Walker, northwestern Tuscaloosa and Fayette Counties through NOON CDT... At 1119 AM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near Bankston, or 10 miles southeast of Fayette, moving east at 15 mph. HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph and penny size hail. SOURCE...Radar indicated.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued June 01 at 8:55AM MST by NWS
entry.summary: ...OZONE HIGH POLLUTION ADVISORY FOR PINAL COUNTY THURSDAY... The Pinal County Department of Air Quality has issued an Ozone High Pollution Advisory for Pinal County including Apache Junction, Casa Grande, Coolidge, and Florence on Thursday. This means that forecast weather conditions combined with existing ozone levels are expected to result in local maximum 8-hour ozone

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 02 at 3:21AM EDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...ELEVATED WILDFIRE POTENTIAL FOR WESTERN UPPER MICHIGAN DUE TO A COMBINATION OF GUSTY WINDS, DRY AND WARM CONDITIONS... Southwest winds gradually become westerly by this afternoon with very deep mixing up to 12 kft expected. As a result, min RH values in the low to mid 20s and westerly gusts of 20-25 mph are expected this afternoon. Scattered showers and isolated thunderstorms

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued June 02 at 10:33AM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...The Clark Fork and Bitterroot Rivers are expected to rise to near minor flood stage early next week... Timing of the event - Sunday into Tuesday Snowmelt combined with precipitation Saturday into Tuesday next week, will increase river flows on the Clark Fork and Bitterroot Rivers. The Clark Fork above Missoula is forecast to

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued June 01 at 12:13PM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...The Bitterroot River in Ravalli County is expected to rise to near minor flood stage early next week... Timing of the event - Monday-Tuesday Snowmelt combined with expected precipitation this week and the weekend, will increase river flows along the Bitterroot River in Ravalli County early next week. The river at Bell Crossing near

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued May 31 at 3:00PM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Runoff has begun, with significant rises on area streams... Area streams have risen the last day or two from significant precipitation that occurred last weekend. This included two to four inches of precipitation in the foothills, and one to three feet of heavy wet snowfall in the higher elevations of the mountains. The newer snow may be ripe to quickly melt off with warmer temperatures

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued May 31 at 3:00PM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Runoff has begun, with significant rises on area streams... Area streams have risen the last day or two from significant precipitation that occurred last weekend. This included two to four inches of precipitation in the foothills, and one to three feet of heavy wet snowfall in the higher elevations of the mountains. The newer snow may be ripe to quickly melt off with warmer temperatures
